In #14458, @Christopher Hoskin proves that the docs#LinearMap.polar set of a submodule (and, more generally, a SubMulAction) is the submodule {y | ∀ x ∈ m, B x y = 0}, then defines polarSubmodule. I tried to search for
@loogle LinearMap, |- Submodule _ _
this submodule for a general Set and failed. Of course, this is ⨅ (x) (_ : x ∈ m), LinearMap.ker (B x). Do we need a separate definition for this? If yes, how should we call it?
:search: Submodule.compatibleMaps, LinearMap.submoduleImage, and 11 more
Looking at the code, I am very surprised to see a cases' in non-ported code. Don’t we have a guideline saying to not do this?
I think that we can fix style issues after we decide about the names and types of theorems/definitions we want to add in this PR.

Patrick Massot said:

Looking at the code, I am very surprised to see a cases' in non-ported code. Don’t we have a guideline saying to not do this?

I couldn't see anything about this here: https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html - is there somewhere else I should be looking?
I think the reality is that cases' x with x hx is easier to type and read than cases x with | _ x hx => ?_
But it’s really ugly compared to rcases x with ⟨x, hx⟩ or obtain ⟨x, hx⟩ := x.
Generally speaking though they mean different things; rcases and obtain don't work correctly on WithTop, because they don't / can't respect cases_eliminator.
#14458 LGTM modulo this decision about polarSubmodule. @Patrick Massot Do you have an opinion about this?
Then I'm going to merge it as is. If someone adds the definition I suggested, we can deduplicate later.
Yury G. Kudryashov has marked this topic as resolved.
